entry.title: Gruf gets superpowers
entry.summary: In my last article article I introduced Gruf, a command line tool for interacting with Gerrit. Since then, Gruf has gained a few important new features. Caching Gruf will now by default cache results for five minutes. This avoids repeatedly querying the server for the same information when you’re just displaying it with different templates (for example, if you run a gruf query open here followed by a gruf -t patches query open here).

entry.title: Gruf, a Gerrit command line utility
entry.summary: (See also the followup to this article.) I’ve recently started spending more time interacting with Gerrit, the code review tool used both by OpenStack, at review.openstack.org, and by a variety of other open source projects at GerritForge’s GitHub-linked review.gerrithub.io. I went looking for command line tools and was largely disappointed with what I found. Many of the solutions out there assume that you’re regularly interacting with a single Gerrit instance, and that’s seldom the case: more often, the Gerrit server in use varies from project to project.
